item.title: HTML Basics: 2
item.description:
This page is a continuation of the previous post about me learning HTML and CSS.

CSS Stands for Cascading Style Sheets, a way to define how HTML pages look. CSS can control how multiple pages look at once. Can be done inline, like with the previously mentioned style options.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <body>
      <h1 style="color:red"> Example Header </h1>
   </body>
</html>

Can also be done internally, within the style HTML tags within the head to set style for all the same elements in the HTML document.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <head>
      <style>
         body {background-color: blue;}
         h1 {color: red;}
         p {color: yellow;}
      </style>
   </head>
</html>

Finally can be done externally with its own CSS file. This is linked to in the head section of a HTML document.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <head>
      <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
   </head>
</html>

CSS has many customizeable options like this, border, margin, padding, etc. Specific html elements can be given an id, image you wanted to have every paragraph but one red, and the last one blue. You can set an internal paragraph style and give the different paragraph a specific id that will only set the color for that one element. This same idea is applicable through the class attribute, instead of one specific id to one specific element, classes of elements with the same styling can be created

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <head>
      <style>
        p {color: red;}
        #pBlue {color: blue:}
        p.exampleClass {color: yellow;}

      </style>
   </head>

   <body>
      <p>Red</p>
      <p>Red</p>
      <p>Red</p>
      <p id="pBlue"> Blue <p>
      <p class="exampleClass"> Example </p>
      <p class="exampleClass"> Same styling, same class </p>
   </body>

</html>

We have already talked about links, but they can also be customized by css, changing appearanece and functionality of links. Images are commonly made into links.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <body>
      <a href="https://Google.com">
         <img src="example.png" alt="Example Image" widith="400" height="200">
      </a>
   </body>
</html>

item.title: Learning HTML: Basics
item.description:
I have created and setup a decent rough outline of my tutoring website (along with buying ritutoring.com and wlhood.com), but I want to edit the theme files to make it look better. I beleive the edits I want to make would be done through CSS, but the two go hand in hand and I’d rather just start with the foundations and learn HTML and CSS and get into good habits before I jump into the weeds more with Java and whatever else I want to get into.

I’m rationalizing this by thinking of the value of having a professional website as a portfolio to show off my skills, and also to force myself in this self-study journey to take notes I can come back to.

Basic HTML

HTML is a tag-based language, it is built with elements. Elements have start and end tags, the end tag being identical except it starts with a forward slash. Elements can be within elements. Some tags like img or br are empty tags, there is only one (see below examples).

  • !DOCTYPE
  • Structure
  • Text & Images
  • Lists
  • Style
  • Formatting

!DOCTYPE

The top line of the html file has this code

<!DOCTYPE html>

Signals that the file is written in HTML5 code. The entire body of the html document is surround by the tag html.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html> 

</html>

Structure

The actual page is split into the head, the meta data of the page, and the body, the actual body of the page. Metadata is information about the page that isnt displayed.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <head>
   
   </head>
   
   <body>
   
   </body>
</html>

Text & Images

Within the header you can set the title, the text displayed on the browser tab. Within the body, titles and subtitles can be made with h1 through h6, largest to smallest. Regular text can be written within paragraphs, p. A line break can be inserted anywhere with br. Images in the same folder as the html document can be inserted with img. A horizontal rule (horizontal line to speerate content) can be inserted with hr.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <head>
      <title> Title </title>
   </head>
   
   <body>
      <h1> Biggest Header</h1>
      <h6> Smallest Header</h6>
      <p> Regular paragraph text</p>
      <p> Broken <br> Paragraph</P>
      <hr>
      
      <img src="example.png" alt="example alt text" width="" height="">
   </body>
</html>

Within the img tag, src signifies the image file name, alt represents the text that will show if for some reason the image cannot be displayed. Width and height set the width and height of the image.

Text within p tags cannot be formamted with spaces and line breaks without tags. Pre tags can be used to retain line breaks and extra spaces between words.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <body>
      <pre>
      Line         breaks
      and     spaces    maintained
      </pre>
      
      <p>
      Line       breaks   
      and    spaces   NOT   maintained
      </p>
   </body>
</html>

Lists

You can make two types of simple lists, ordered and unordered. Unordered lists are marked with bullet points, ordered lists are marked with increasing numbers. ul and ol determine unordered/ordered, and every list item is denoted with li.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
   <body>
   
      <ul>
         <li> Ex List Item </li>
      </ul>
      
      <ol>
         <li> Ex List Item </li>
      </ol>
      
   </body>
</html>

####Style Color, font, and size can be set with the style attribute. Attributes go within the start tag of an element, and effect only that element. Other attributes are img.

Style’s use CSS to change color, size, etc.

lang: Attribute for html to set language title: Attribute for p to create tooltip background-color: Attribute for body to set background color

Attribute text should be in double quotes, or single quotes if neccesary.

<html lang="en">
   <body>
      <p style="color: red"> Colored Text </p>
      <p title="Tooltip when hovered"> Paragraph </p>
   </body>
</html>

Formatting

Text can be further formatted with tags within text elements.

item.title: Creating This Website
item.description:
This simple personal website was made following this book: blogdown: Creating Websites with R Markdown

I am using it as a simple, easily managed portfolio and personal website, documenting personal projects and other content.

Technologies Used:

  • Markdown (Using Typora)
  • R (Using R Studio)
  • Github
  • Netlify

All posts are written in Typora, my preferred Markdown editor. Markdown is a simple markup language, that I think makes exceptionally clean and modern websites.

The website is generated using blogdown and hugo, as described in the mentioned book. The theme is Academic, which again I think is lightweight and stylish.

As the website is edited or new posts created, the files are updated in a Github repository that is then linked to Netlify and automatically updated.

As of writing this, my next aim is to further customize and optimize the site for my purposes, and to purchase and setup a domain name, along with launching a similar website for my planned tutoring business.
